verses.text: After these things, God tested Abraham and said to him, "Abraham!" He replied, "Here I am."
verses.comment: Here, the narrative introduces a 'test' from God, indicating this is a divine trial of faith, not a temptation to evil (cf. James 1:13).

verses.text: Then He said, "Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains that I will show you."
verses.comment: God asks Abraham for what is most precious to him. 'Land of Moriah' is later associated with Jerusalem's temple mount (2 Chr. 3:1), linking the binding of Isaac with the temple and sacrificial worship. Note the echo of God sacrificing His 'only beloved Son' (John 3:16; Rom. 8:32).

verses.text: So Abraham rose early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, and his son Isaac. He split the wood for the burnt offering, and set out for the place that God had told him about.
verses.comment: Abraham's prompt obedience marks profound faith, reminiscent of his earlier responses to God's voice (Gen. 12:4).

verses.text: On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place from a distance.
verses.comment: The 'third day' often represents a period of trial culminating in revelation or deliverance (cf. Hos. 6:2, Christ's resurrection after three days in 1 Cor. 15:4).

verses.text: Abraham said to his young men, "Stay here with the donkey. I and the boy will go there and worship and return to you."
verses.comment: Abraham speaks as if both he and Isaac will return—showing either faith in God's promise or confidence in restoration (cf. Hebrews 11:19).

verses.text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and laid it on Isaac his son, and he took in his hand the fire and the knife. So the two of them walked on together.
verses.comment: Isaac carrying the wood prefigures Jesus carrying His cross (John 19:17), a deeply significant allusion in Christian tradition.

verses.text: Then Isaac spoke to Abraham his father, and said, "My father!" And he said, "Here I am, my son." He said, "Look, the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?"
verses.comment: Isaac's question highlights his innocence and trust, and sets the stage for Abraham's faith-filled answer.

verses.text: Abraham replied, "God Himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son." So the two of them went on together.
verses.comment: "God will provide" (Hebrew: 'Jireh')—a profound expression of faith. Later interpreted by Christians as pointing to Christ, 'the Lamb of God' (John 1:29).

verses.text: When they came to the place that God had told him about, Abraham built the altar there and arranged the wood. He bound Isaac his son and laid him on the altar, on top of the wood.
verses.comment: "Bound Isaac"—this act (the 'Binding of Isaac') is central in biblical and later Jewish and Christian thought, symbolizing total submission and trust in God's will.

verses.text: Then Abraham reached out his hand and took the knife to slay his son.
verses.comment: Abraham raised the knife, completing his obedience to the utmost limit—an action highly praised in later Scripture (James 2:21).

verses.text: But the Angel of the LORD called out to him from heaven and said, "Abraham, Abraham!" So he answered, "Here I am."
verses.comment: The repetition of Abraham's name marks urgency and intimacy. The 'Angel of the LORD' often signals a divine appearance (theophany).

verses.text: He said, "Do not lay your hand on the boy or do anything to him, for now I know that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only son, from Me."
verses.comment: God affirms Abraham's total faith and obedience—commemorated as an exemplar of faith for all generations (cf. Heb. 11:17–19).

verses.text: Abraham lifted his eyes and looked, and there behind him was a ram caught in a thicket by its horns. So Abraham went and took the ram and offered it up as a burnt offering instead of his son.
verses.comment: The ram provided by God as a substitute prefigures Christ's sacrificial death for sinners (cf. 1 Pet. 3:18; 2 Cor. 5:21). The principle of substitutionary atonement is here foreshadowed.

verses.text: So Abraham called the name of that place "The LORD Will Provide"; as it is said to this day, "On the mountain of the LORD it will be provided."
verses.comment: 'The LORD Will Provide' (YHWH Jireh) points to God's ongoing provision. The mountain becomes the enduring site of divine provision—see related Eucharistic typology in later Christian interpretation.

verses.text: Then the Angel of the LORD called to Abraham a second time from heaven
verses.comment: A second divine communication follows Abraham's obedient act. The repetition underscores significance.

verses.text: and said, "By Myself I have sworn, declares the LORD, because you have done this thing, and have not withheld your son, your only son,
verses.comment: God swears by Himself to underline the certainty and gravity of His promise. This oath becomes foundational for later biblical promises (Heb. 6:13–14).

verses.text: I will surely bless you, and I will multiply your offspring as the stars of heaven and as the sand on the seashore. And your offspring will possess the gate of His enemies.
verses.comment: The blessing expands the covenant promises (cf. Gen. 13:16). 'Offspring' has a collective sense, but may also point to a singular figure (cf. Gal. 3:16). Victory over enemies anticipates messianic kingship.

verses.text: In your seed all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice."
verses.comment: 'Seed' (singular and collective) is interpreted in the New Testament as referring to Christ (Gal. 3:16). Obedience brings universal blessing—a foreshadowing of God's plan for all peoples.

verses.text: Then Abraham returned to his young men, and they arose and went together to Beersheba. And Abraham stayed at Beersheba.
verses.comment: Isaac is not mentioned, creating space for later interpretations that Isaac, like Christ, was 'as good as dead' and 'returned' (Heb. 11:19, typology).

verses.text: Now after these things it was told to Abraham, 'Look, Milcah also has borne children to your brother Nahor:
verses.comment: The genealogy here connects Abraham to his wider family, serving as a historical anchor for the narrative and preparation for Isaac’s future marriage.

verses.text: Uz his firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram,
verses.comment: The listing of Nahor's family members highlights the interconnectedness of God's plans despite the text's primary focus on Abraham.

verses.text: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel."
verses.comment: Genealogical precision underscores the importance of lineage in the unfolding biblical story leading to the fulfillment of God's promises.

verses.text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. These eight were born to Milcah by Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
verses.comment: Rebekah is introduced as the future wife of Isaac, showing God's providence continues through specific chosen families.

verses.text: His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
verses.comment: This closure on Nahor's family tree brings the focus to the coming generations. Scripture’s careful attention to lineage foreshadows the coming of Messiah through chosen ancestry.
